title: ClusMFL: A Cluster-Enhanced Framework for Modality-Incomplete Multimodal Federated Learning in Brain Imaging Analysis
author: Xinpeng Wang (Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen), Rong Zhou (Lehigh University), Han Xie (Emory University), Xiaoying Tang (Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen), Lifang He (Lehigh University), Carl Yang (Emory University)
relevance_why: This paper's focus on multimodal federated learning can contribute to audio-language alignment and audio enhancement tasks by introducing innovative methodologies that may be adaptable to audio data.
background: The study addresses the challenge of incomplete modalities in federated learning for brain imaging, aiming to improve model performance despite some data being unavailable.
contribution: ClusMFL introduces a novel framework leveraging clustering and modality-aware aggregation to improve learning in modality-incomplete settings, achieving superior performance on brain imaging datasets.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods typically assumed complete modalities or oversimplified missing data, leading to suboptimal results in healthcare applications.
technical_comparison.novelty: ClusMFL effectively utilizes clustering to represent diverse data distributions and improves feature alignment and modality completion compared to traditional methods.

key_innovation: Employs FINCH clustering to create an adaptable representation of feature distributions, enabling effective cross-modal learning even with missing modalities.
real_world_impact: The proposed framework shows promise in enhancing diagnostic accuracy in healthcare settings, directly addressing challenges in collaborative medical data analysis.

new_terms.Multimodal Federated Learning (MFL): **Multimodal Federated Learning** refers to the process of training machine learning models across multiple disparate data sources (e.g., imaging modalities) while preserving data privacy.
new_terms.FINCH clustering: **FINCH clustering** is a parameter-free clustering algorithm that groups features into clusters based on nearest neighbor relationships.
